title: Explain the difference between HTML5's <article> and <section> elements. When should each be used?
content: A senior developer needs to understand semantic HTML5 elements. When would you use <article> vs <section>, and what are the accessibility implications?
explanation: <article> represents independent, self-contained content that could be distributed (like blog posts, news articles). <section> represents a thematic grouping of content, typically with a heading. Articles can contain sections, and sections can contain articles. Use <article> for standalone content, <section> for organizing related content.

options.text: <article> is for standalone content that makes sense independently; <section> is for thematic grouping of related content
options.explanation: Correct. <article> should be independently distributable, while <section> groups related content thematically.

options.text: <article> and <section> are interchangeable and can be used based on personal preference
options.explanation: Incorrect. They have distinct semantic meanings that affect accessibility and SEO.

options.text: <section> is always nested inside <article>, never the reverse
options.explanation: Incorrect. Articles can contain sections, and sections can contain articles depending on the content structure.

options.text: <article> is for blog posts only, <section> is for everything else
options.explanation: Incorrect. <article> can represent any standalone content (forum posts, comments, widgets, etc.), not just blog posts.

hints: Consider what makes content 'standalone' vs 'thematic grouping'
Think about how screen readers interpret these elements
Remember that semantic HTML affects both accessibility and SEO

title: What is the purpose of the 'defer' and 'async' attributes on <script> tags, and when should each be used?
content: As a senior developer optimizing page load performance, explain the differences between defer, async, and neither attribute on script tags, including execution order and DOM readiness.
explanation: Without attributes: script blocks HTML parsing. 'async': downloads in parallel, executes immediately when ready (order not guaranteed). 'defer': downloads in parallel, executes after HTML parsing completes, in document order. Use 'async' for independent scripts (analytics). Use 'defer' for scripts that depend on DOM or need execution order.

options.text: 'async' executes as soon as downloaded (order not guaranteed); 'defer' executes after HTML parsing in document order
options.explanation: Correct. 'async' prioritizes speed but loses execution order. 'defer' maintains order and waits for DOM.

options.text: Both 'async' and 'defer' execute scripts in the same order they appear in the document
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'async' scripts execute as soon as they're downloaded, which may not match document order.

options.text: 'defer' blocks HTML parsing, 'async' does not
options.explanation: Incorrect. Both allow parallel downloading. Neither blocks parsing, but scripts without attributes do block parsing.

options.text: 'async' and 'defer' are identical in behavior, just different syntax
options.explanation: Incorrect. They have fundamentally different execution timing and ordering guarantees.

hints: Consider when scripts need DOM elements to be available
Think about dependencies between multiple scripts
Remember that blocking parsing affects perceived performance

title: Explain the difference between ARIA roles and native HTML5 semantic elements. When should you use each?
content: A senior developer must understand accessibility. When should you use ARIA roles (role='button', role='navigation') vs native semantic elements (<button>, <nav>)? What are the implications?
explanation: Always prefer native semantic HTML elements (<button>, <nav>, <main>) over ARIA roles because native elements provide built-in keyboard support, focus management, and browser behavior. Use ARIA roles only when native elements cannot achieve the desired interaction pattern (e.g., complex widgets, custom components). ARIA should enhance, not replace, semantic HTML.

options.text: Prefer native semantic elements; use ARIA only when native elements cannot achieve the interaction pattern
options.explanation: Correct. Native elements provide built-in accessibility features. ARIA is a fallback for custom components.

options.text: ARIA roles are always better because they're more explicit and modern
options.explanation: Incorrect. ARIA should complement, not replace, semantic HTML. Native elements provide more built-in functionality.

options.text: Use ARIA roles on all interactive elements for better screen reader support
options.explanation: Incorrect. Redundant ARIA on native elements can actually confuse screen readers. Use ARIA only when necessary.

options.text: Native elements and ARIA roles are equivalent, choose based on team preference
options.explanation: Incorrect. Native elements provide keyboard support, focus management, and browser behavior that ARIA alone cannot replicate.

hints: Consider what built-in behaviors native elements provide (keyboard, focus, etc.)
Think about the 'no ARIA is better than bad ARIA' principle
Remember that ARIA enhances, not replaces, semantic HTML

title: What is the difference between <meta name='viewport'> and <meta http-equiv='X-UA-Compatible'>? Explain their impact on rendering.
content: Senior developers need to understand how meta tags affect browser rendering. Explain these two meta tags and when each is necessary.
explanation: <meta name='viewport'> controls mobile rendering, setting initial scale and width (e.g., width=device-width, initial-scale=1). <meta http-equiv='X-UA-Compatible'> forces IE/Edge to use a specific rendering engine version (e.g., IE=edge). Viewport is essential for responsive design. X-UA-Compatible is legacy for IE compatibility.

options.text: Viewport controls mobile responsive rendering; X-UA-Compatible forces IE/Edge rendering engine version
options.explanation: Correct. Viewport is for responsive design on mobile devices. X-UA-Compatible is for legacy IE compatibility.

options.text: Both control the same thing but for different browsers
options.explanation: Incorrect. They serve completely different purposes: viewport for responsive design, X-UA-Compatible for IE compatibility mode.

options.text: X-UA-Compatible is required for all modern browsers to render correctly
options.explanation: Incorrect. X-UA-Compatible is only needed for legacy IE/Edge compatibility. Modern browsers don't need it.

options.text: Viewport is optional and only affects desktop browsers
options.explanation: Incorrect. Viewport is essential for mobile responsive design and affects how mobile browsers render pages.

hints: Consider which browsers need X-UA-Compatible
Think about what 'responsive design' means for mobile devices
Remember that modern browsers have different requirements than legacy IE

title: Explain the Content Security Policy (CSP) meta tag and how it prevents XSS attacks. What are the key directives?
content: Security is critical for senior developers. How does CSP work, what directives are most important, and how does it prevent XSS?
explanation: CSP restricts which resources (scripts, styles, images) can be loaded and executed, preventing XSS by blocking inline scripts and unauthorized sources. Key directives: default-src (fallback), script-src (JavaScript sources), style-src (CSS sources), img-src (images), connect-src (AJAX/fetch). 'unsafe-inline' and 'unsafe-eval' should be avoided when possible.

options.text: CSP restricts resource loading sources, preventing XSS by blocking unauthorized scripts/styles. Key directives: default-src, script-src, style-src
options.explanation: Correct. CSP is a security mechanism that whitelists allowed sources for resources, preventing injection attacks.

options.text: CSP only prevents clickjacking, not XSS attacks
options.explanation: Incorrect. CSP primarily prevents XSS by controlling script execution. X-Frame-Options prevents clickjacking.

options.text: CSP allows all inline scripts by default for convenience
options.explanation: Incorrect. CSP blocks inline scripts by default. 'unsafe-inline' must be explicitly added, but it reduces security.

options.text: CSP is only needed for sites with user-generated content
options.explanation: Incorrect. CSP should be used on all sites as defense-in-depth, not just sites with user content.

hints: Think about how XSS attacks inject malicious scripts
Consider what 'whitelist' vs 'blacklist' means for security
Remember that CSP is a defense-in-depth strategy

title: What is the difference between <iframe sandbox> and regular <iframe>? What security restrictions does sandbox enforce?
content: Senior developers must understand iframe security. Explain sandbox attribute restrictions and when to use it.
explanation: <iframe sandbox> applies strict security restrictions: blocks scripts, forms, popups, plugins, and top-level navigation by default. You can selectively allow features with tokens like 'allow-scripts', 'allow-forms', 'allow-same-origin'. Regular <iframe> has no such restrictions. Use sandbox for untrusted content (user-generated, third-party widgets).

options.text: Sandbox blocks scripts, forms, popups by default; tokens like 'allow-scripts' can selectively enable features
options.explanation: Correct. Sandbox is a security feature that restricts iframe capabilities, with opt-in tokens for specific features.

options.text: Sandbox and regular iframe have identical security properties
options.explanation: Incorrect. Sandbox applies strict restrictions that regular iframes don't have.

options.text: Sandbox allows all features by default, you disable them with tokens
options.explanation: Incorrect. Sandbox blocks everything by default and requires explicit tokens to allow features.

options.text: Sandbox is only for styling purposes, not security
options.explanation: Incorrect. Sandbox is specifically a security feature to isolate untrusted content.

hints: Think about what 'sandbox' means in security contexts
Consider the principle of least privilege
Remember that untrusted content needs isolation

title: Explain the <template> element and how it differs from hidden <div> elements. When should you use <template>?
content: Modern HTML5 features for senior developers. What is the <template> element, how does the browser handle it, and what are the performance implications?
explanation: <template> content is inert (not rendered, scripts don't run, images don't load) until cloned via JavaScript. Hidden <div> elements are still parsed, can trigger resource loading, and are part of the DOM. Use <template> for client-side templating, reusable component structures, or when you need truly inert content that won't affect page load.

options.text: <template> content is inert until cloned; hidden <div> is still parsed and can load resources
options.explanation: Correct. <template> is truly inert, while hidden elements are still processed by the browser.

options.text: <template> and hidden <div> behave identically
options.explanation: Incorrect. <template> is inert and doesn't trigger resource loading or script execution until cloned.

options.text: Hidden <div> is better for performance because it's simpler
options.explanation: Incorrect. Hidden divs still consume resources during parsing. <template> is more efficient for unused content.

options.text: <template> automatically renders its content on page load
options.explanation: Incorrect. <template> content is inert and never renders automatically. It must be cloned via JavaScript.

hints: Consider what 'inert' means in browser parsing
Think about resource loading and script execution
Remember that performance matters for unused content

title: What is the purpose of the 'preload', 'prefetch', and 'preconnect' resource hints? When should each be used?
content: Performance optimization for senior developers. Explain these <link> resource hints and their impact on page load performance.
explanation: 'preload' fetches critical resources early (fonts, critical CSS) for current page. 'prefetch' hints at resources for next navigation (next page assets). 'preconnect' establishes early connection to third-party domains (CDNs, APIs). Use preload for critical current-page resources, prefetch for likely next-page resources, preconnect for external domains you'll request from.

options.text: preload: critical current-page resources; prefetch: next-page resources; preconnect: early connection to external domains
options.explanation: Correct. Each hint serves a different optimization purpose: current page, next page, or connection establishment.

options.text: All three hints do the same thing with different syntax
options.explanation: Incorrect. They have distinct purposes: preload for current page, prefetch for next page, preconnect for connections.

options.text: prefetch is for critical resources, preload is for optional resources
options.explanation: Incorrect. It's the opposite: preload is for critical current-page resources, prefetch is for likely next-page resources.

options.text: preconnect automatically downloads and executes resources
options.explanation: Incorrect. preconnect only establishes the connection (DNS, TCP, TLS), it doesn't download resources.

hints: Think about the timing: current page vs next page
Consider what 'establishing a connection' means (DNS, TCP, TLS)
Remember that resource hints are about optimization, not requirements

title: What is the difference between block-level and inline-block elements? Explain their box model behavior.
content: Senior developers must understand CSS box model implications. How do block, inline, and inline-block elements differ in terms of width, height, margins, and layout?
explanation: Block elements take full width, start on new line, respect width/height. Inline elements flow within text, ignore width/height, only respect horizontal margins. Inline-block combines both: flows inline but respects width/height like block elements.

options.explanation: Correct. Block elements take full width, start on new line, respect width/height. Inline elements flow within text, ignore width/height, only respect horizontal margins. Inline-block combines both: flows inline but respects width/height like block elements.

title: Explain the difference between HTML entities (&, <) and character references (A, A). When should each be used?

explanation: Named entities (&, <) are readable and common. Numeric references (A decimal, A hex) work for any Unicode character. Use entities for special characters (<, >, &, quotes). Use numeric for rare Unicode or when entity names aren't available.

title: What is the purpose of the DOCTYPE declaration? What happens if you omit it or use an incorrect DOCTYPE?

explanation: DOCTYPE tells the browser which HTML version to use, triggering standards mode vs quirks mode. Missing/incorrect DOCTYPE causes quirks mode: inconsistent rendering, box model issues, layout bugs. Always use <!DOCTYPE html> for HTML5.

title: Explain the difference between absolute and relative URLs. What are the security and performance implications?
content: URL resolution matters for security and performance. When should you use absolute vs relative URLs, and what are the risks?
explanation: Absolute URLs include protocol and domain (https://example.com/page). Relative URLs are resolved from current page location (/page, ../page). Absolute URLs prevent protocol-relative issues but are verbose. Relative URLs are shorter but can break with base tag changes. Use absolute for external, relative for internal.

title: Explain CSRF protection in HTML forms. How do hidden tokens and SameSite cookies help prevent attacks?
content: Security is critical for forms. Explain Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) attacks and how HTML form attributes help prevent them.
explanation: CSRF tricks users into submitting forms to attacker's site. Protection: hidden CSRF tokens (server validates), SameSite cookie attribute (Strict/Lax prevents cross-site sends), referrer checking. HTML alone can't fully prevent CSRF; need server-side validation. SameSite='Strict' is strongest protection.

title: Explain the Web Storage API (localStorage and sessionStorage). What are the differences and use cases?

explanation: localStorage persists across browser sessions (until cleared). sessionStorage persists only for tab session (cleared on tab close). Both store key-value pairs (strings only, ~5-10MB limit). localStorage for user preferences, sessionStorage for temporary data. Both are synchronous, can block main thread.

title: Which meta tags are essential for SEO? (Select all that apply)

title: What is the difference between 'noindex' and 'nofollow' in robots meta tags?
content: Controlling search engine behavior requires understanding robots directives. Explain noindex vs nofollow.
explanation: 'noindex' prevents page from appearing in search results (page not indexed). 'nofollow' tells crawlers not to follow links on page (links not crawled, no PageRank passed). Can combine: 'noindex, nofollow'. Use noindex for private pages, nofollow for untrusted links.

options.explanation: Incorrect. Both apply to pages, not content types.

options.explanation: Incorrect. Both are valid and serve different purposes.

title: What is the difference between IndexedDB and Web Storage?
content: Client-side storage has multiple options. Explain when to use IndexedDB vs localStorage/sessionStorage.
explanation: Web Storage (localStorage/sessionStorage) is simple key-value store, synchronous, ~5-10MB limit, strings only. IndexedDB is object database, asynchronous, larger storage (~50% of disk), supports complex queries, indexes, transactions. Use Web Storage for simple data, IndexedDB for complex structured data.

options.explanation: Incorrect. They have fundamentally different capabilities.

options.explanation: Incorrect. IndexedDB is asynchronous and can be faster for large datasets.

options.text: IndexedDB is deprecated, use Web Storage
options.explanation: Incorrect. Both are valid, IndexedDB is more powerful.
